choices.text: Between outer nuclear layer and outer plexiform layer
Between inner limiting membrane and nerve fiber layer
Between posterior hyaloid membrane and inner limiting membrane
Between inner nuclear layer and inner plexiform layer

questions.text: Where is the subhyaloid space located?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The subhyaloid space is specifically located as a potential space between the posterior hyaloid membrane and the inner limiting membrane of the retina. The posterior hyaloid membrane, which is a condensation of vitreous fibrils, remains loosely attached to the inner limiting membrane throughout life.

  • The vitreous is situated adjacent to the retina posteriorly and the ciliary body, zonules, and lens anteriorly.
  • The condensation of vitreous fibrils forms "false anatomic membranes": the anterior hyaloid membrane (anterior to the ora serrata) and the posterior hyaloid membrane (posterior to the ora).
  • The subhyaloid space, though a potential space, is generally not discernible in a normal eye unless the lens has been extracted and a posterior vitreous detachment has occurred.

Explanation of Other Options:

Between outer nuclear layer and outer plexiform layer (Option A): These are layers within the retina itself. The subhyaloid space is external to the retina, between the vitreous face and the retina's innermost layer.

Between inner limiting membrane and nerve fiber layer (Option B): The inner limiting membrane is the innermost layer of the retina, and the nerve fiber layer is directly beneath it. There is no subhyaloid space located between these two retinal layers. The subhyaloid space is on top of the inner limiting membrane.

Between inner nuclear layer and inner plexiform layer (Option D): These are also layers within the retina. The subhyaloid space is located at the vitreoretinal interface, outside these specific retinal layers.

Key Takeaways:

  • The subhyaloid space is a potential space situated between the posterior hyaloid membrane of the vitreous and the inner limiting membrane of the retina.
  • It is not typically visible unless a posterior vitreous detachment has occurred.

questions.text: What is the volume of vitreous?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vitreous humour is an inert, transparent, jelly-like structure that fills approximately four-fifths (80%) of the cavity of the eyeball. Its volume is about 4 mL.

  • The vitreous body has a somewhat spherical shape posteriorly and features a cup-shaped depression anteriorly, known as the patellar fossa.
  • This shape allows it to conform to the contour of the retina posteriorly and the lens anteriorly.
  • In terms of weight, it is approximately 4 gm.

Key Takeaways:

  • The vitreous humour occupies the majority of the eyeball's volume (80%).
  • Its approximate volume is 4 mL, and its weight is about 4 gm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a macular retinal dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leber congenital amaurosis is classified as a generalised photoreceptor dystrophy, meaning it involves the entire retina, typically affecting the peripheral retina more than the macula. Therefore, it is not a macular retinal dystrophy.

Common retinal dystrophies can be broadly categorized:

  • Generalised photoreceptor dystrophies: These involve the entire retina (with a greater impact on the peripheral retina than the macula). Examples include:
    • Typical retinitis pigmentosa and its variants
    • Progressive cone dystrophy
    • Leber congenital amaurosis
    • Congenital stationary night blindness
    • Congenital monochromatism (achromatopsia)
  • Macular dystrophies: These primarily affect the macular area of the retina.

Explanation of Other Options:

Juvenile Best's macular dystrophy (Option A): This is explicitly listed as one of the common macular dystrophies, primarily involving the macular area.

Stargardt's disease (Option B): This is also a common macular dystrophy, affecting the macular area.

Vitelliform dystrophy (Option C): This is another condition specifically listed as a common macular dystrophy, characterized by its primary involvement of the macular area.

Key Takeaways:

  • Leber congenital amaurosis is a generalised photoreceptor dystrophy, not a macular dystrophy.
  • Juvenile Best's macular dystrophy, Stargardt's disease, and Vitelliform dystrophy are all examples of macular dystrophies, meaning they primarily affect the macula.

Contains the primary vitreous at birth

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cloquet's canal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the provided statements about Cloquet's canal are true. It is an anatomical structure in vitreous humor.

  • Cloquet's canal is a canal that runs straight from the lens to the optic disc.
  • In a fetus, the hyaloid artery runs through it. This artery is responsible for nourishing the developing lens.
  • At birth, Cloquet's canal contains the primary vitreous, which is the embryonic remnant of the vitreous that surrounds the hyaloid artery.
  • Later in life, the secondary vitreous (which forms around the primary vitreous) eventually becomes liquefied and shrinks.
  • Between 40 and 70 years of age (and earlier in myopes), vitreous liquefaction or syneresis occurs, causing the vitreous mass to shrink and collapse, leading to its separation from the retina, a condition known as Posterior Vitreous Detachment (PVD).
  • Condensations of vitreous fibrils within this liquefied vitreous are visible as floaters.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cloquet's canal is a remnant of embryonic development, extending from the lens to the optic disc.
  • It historically housed the hyaloid artery in the foetus and contains the primary vitreous at birth.

choices.text: Attachment to posterior surface of lens

questions.text: Which attachment of vitreous is known as vitreous base?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vitreous base refers specifically to the part of the vitreous that is strongly attached to the ora serrata. This attachment spans about 4 mm across the ora serrata and represents the strongest point of vitreous adhesion to the surrounding structures.

The outer surface of the vitreous cortex is attached to various surrounding structures:

  • Vitreous base: Located about 4 mm across the ora serrata, this is where the attachment of the vitreous is strongest.
  • Anterior face of vitreous cortex: This part is attached to the posterior surface of the lens via the ligament of Wiegert.
  • Posterior face of vitreous cortex: This has moderate adhesions to the retina:
    • Around the margins of the optic disc.
    • Around the fovea (where the attachment is weaker than around the disc).
    • In the rest of the retina, the vitreous cortex is loosely attached to the internal limiting membrane, with slightly less looseness along the major retinal vessels.

Explanation of Other Options:

Attachment to optic disc (Option B): While the vitreous cortex has moderate adhesions around the margins of the optic disc, this specific attachment is not referred to as the "vitreous base."

Attachment to macula (Option C): The vitreous cortex has a weaker attachment around the fovea (part of the macula) compared to the optic disc, and this is not termed the "vitreous base."

Attachment to posterior surface of lens (Option D): The attachment to the posterior surface of the lens is via the ligament of Wiegert, which is distinct from the vitreous base at the ora serrata.

Key Takeaways:

  • The vitreous base is defined by the strongest attachment of the vitreous to the ora serrata, spanning approximately 4 mm.
  • Other significant vitreous attachments include those to the lens (ligament of Wiegert), optic disc, and macula, but these are distinct from the vitreous base.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male born to parents in a consanguineous marriage presents with the complaint of difficulty in night vision. Fundus examination is as shown in the picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation with difficulty in night vision at a young age, a history of consanguineous marriage (suggesting a recessive inheritance pattern), and the characteristic fundus findings shown in the picture strongly point to Retinitis pigmentosa (RP). The image visually demonstrates diffuse retinal degeneration with prominent bone-spicule pigmentation and attenuated retinal vessels, which are hallmarks of RP.

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a hereditary disorder, primarily affecting the photoreceptors (with rods typically affected more than cones), leading to progressive vision loss. It is also known as primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy.
  • The inheritance of Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) can occur as:
    • Sporadic disorder (40-50%)
    • Inherited disorder (Autosomal dominant RP (adRP), Autosomal recessive RP (arRP), X-linked recessive (XLR))
    • Digenic inheritance (very rare)
  • Key symptoms include: Night blindness (nyctalopia), delayed dark adaptation, progressive loss of peripheral vision, and in severe cases, complete loss of vision.

Explanation of Other Options:

Vitelliform dystrophy (Option A): Vitelliform dystrophy (e.g., Best's disease) is a macular dystrophy characterized by an egg-yolk-like lesion in the macula, primarily affecting central vision and not typically associated with early severe night blindness or the diffuse retinal pigmentation seen in the image.

Stargardt's disease (Option B): Stargardt's disease is a common macular dystrophy presenting with central vision loss and often a "beaten bronze" appearance or pisciform (fish-tail shaped) flecks in the macula. While it can be inherited recessively, its primary symptom is central vision loss, and it lacks the extensive peripheral pigmentary changes characteristic of RP.

Best's macular dystrophy (Option D): Best's macular dystrophy is a specific type of vitelliform dystrophy, characterized by a vitelliform lesion in the macula. It primarily affects central vision and is an autosomal dominant condition, which doesn't fit all aspects of the patient's presentation (especially night blindness as the primary complaint and the diffuse fundus changes).

Key Takeaways:

  • Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is strongly suggested by night blindness, consanguineous parents, and the characteristic fundus findings (like bone-spicule pigmentation and attenuated vessels as seen in the image).
  • RP is a progressive, inherited photoreceptor dystrophy that leads to peripheral vision loss.

choices.text: Occurs due to failure of regression in structures of primary vitreous

questions.text: Which of the following is true about PHPV (Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the provided statements accurately describe characteristics of Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV).

  • PHPV occurs due to a failure of the structures within the primary vitreous to regress during fetal development.
  • It is mostly unilateral, meaning it typically affects only one eye.
  • PHPV often presents shortly after birth as a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in a full-term infant.
  • It may also be associated with other ocular abnormalities such as cataract, glaucoma, long and extended ciliary processes, microphthalmos, and intraocular hemorrhage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV) is a developmental anomaly resulting from the failure of primary vitreous structures to regress.
  • It is typically unilateral and commonly presents with leukocoria in infants.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common ocular association in retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypermetropia (farsightedness) is not listed as a common ocular association with retinitis pigmentosa. The common ocular associations include myopia, primary open-angle glaucoma, microphthalmos, conical cornea (keratoconus), and posterior subcapsular cataract.

Ocular associations of retinitis pigmentosa commonly include:

  • Myopia (Option A ruled out)
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma (Option B ruled out)
  • Microphthalmos
  • Conical cornea (keratoconus)(Option D ruled out)
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract

Key Takeaways:

  • While myopia, primary open-angle glaucoma, and keratoconus are common ocular associations with retinitis pigmentosa, hypermetropia is not.
  • Other associated conditions include microphthalmos and posterior subcapsular cataract.

choices.text: At the posterior surface of lens

questions.text: Bergmeister papilla is the remains of primary vitreous in which part of the eye?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bergmeister papilla is explicitly described as a small remnant of the primary vitreous system appearing as a tuft of tissue at the optic disc. This occurs due to the incomplete involution of the hyaloid vessel and primary vitreous during eye development.

  • During eye development, a hyaloid vessel runs between the optic nerve and the back of the lens, carrying nutrients and oxygen.
  • This hyaloid vessel, along with its surrounding embryonic material, constitutes the primary vitreous.
  • The hyaloid vessels and primary vitreous normally begin to involute in the second month of gestation, giving way to the secondary vitreous (the vitreous humor).
  • Small remnants of this system are common in healthy adults:
    • Bergmeister papilla: A tuft of tissue found at the optic disc.
    • Mittendorf dot: A tag of tissue located on the posterior capsule of the lens.
  • Extensive remnants of this "hyaloid vessel - primary vitreous" system lead to a condition known as Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV).

Explanation of Other Options:

At the posterior surface of lens (Option A): A remnant of primary vitreous on the posterior capsule is called a Mittendorf dot, not Bergmeister papilla.

At the macula (Option C): There is no specific remnant of the primary vitreous named "Bergmeister papilla" associated with the macula.

At the ora serrata (Option D): The ora serrata is associated with the strongest attachment of the vitreous (vitreous base), but not specifically with Bergmeister papilla, which is an optic disc remnant.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bergmeister papilla is a normal anatomical variant, representing a remnant of the primary vitreous at the optic disc.
  • Another common remnant is the Mittendorf dot, found on the posterior lens capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Refsum's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Polydactyly is not a characteristic feature of Refsum's syndrome. Refsum's syndrome is specifically characterized by a triad of symptoms related to neurological and retinal degeneration.

  • Refsum's syndrome is characterized by the following features:
    • Retinitis pigmentosa (progressive vision loss, especially night blindness and peripheral vision). (Option C rule out)
    • Peripheral neuropathy (nerve damage affecting the extremities). (Option A rule out)
    • Cerebellar ataxia (impaired coordination and balance due to cerebellar dysfunction). (Option B rule out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Refsum's syndrome is primarily identified by the presence of retinitis pigmentosa, peripheral neuropathy, and cerebellar ataxia.
  • Polydactyly (the presence of extra fingers or toes) is not a described feature of Refsum's syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with complaints of diminished night vision for two years. On fundus examination, he was found to have features of retinitis pigmentosa. Systemic examination showed obesity, mental defect, polydactyly and hypogonadism. What is the most probable syndrome he's suffering from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The constellation of symptoms presented by the 20-year-old male-diminished night vision with fundus features of retinitis pigmentosa, combined with systemic findings of obesity, mental defect, polydactyly, and hypogonadism-is the classic presentation of Laurence-Moon-Biedl-Bardet syndrome.

Explanation of Other Options:

Usher syndrome (Option A): Usher syndrome is characterized by retinitis pigmentosa and sensorineural hearing loss. It does not typically include obesity, polydactyly, or hypogonadism.

Refsum's syndrome (Option C): Refsum's syndrome is characterized by retinitis pigmentosa, peripheral neuropathy, and cerebellar ataxia. It does not typically involve obesity, polydactyly, hypogonadism, or significant mental defect as primary features.

Cockayne's syndrome (Option D): Cockayne's syndrome involves features such as severe growth failure, intellectual disability, photosensitivity, hearing loss, and premature aging. While some ocular features (like cataracts or retinal degeneration) can occur, it does not typically present with the specific combination of retinitis pigmentosa, obesity, polydactyly, and hypogonadism.

Key Takeaways:

  • The presence of retinitis pigmentosa alongside obesity, mental defect, polydactyly, and hypogonadism is the defining characteristic of Laurence-Moon-Biedl-Bardet syndrome.
  • This syndrome is a ciliopathy affecting multiple organ systems.

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern of Wagner's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wagner's syndrome has an autosomal dominant (AD) inheritance pattern.

Wagner's syndrome is characterized by several features:

  • The vitreous is liquified with condensed membranes.
  • The retina may show narrow and sheathed vessels, along with pigmented spots in the periphery.
  • The choroid may be atrophied.
  • Cataracts may develop as a late complication.

Key Takeaways:

  • Wagner's syndrome follows an autosomal dominant inheritance
  • Key features include vitreous liquefaction, retinal vessel changes, choroidal atrophy, and potential late-onset cataracts.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for sex-linked juvenile retinoschisis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement that ERG and EOG both are normal is not true for sex-linked juvenile retinoschisis. The ERG (electroretinogram) is subnormal, while the EOG (electro-oculogram) is normal.(Option C ruled out)

  • Sex-linked juvenile retinoschisis is a common bilateral dystrophy of the central retina.(Option B ruled out)
  • It is caused by a splitting of the sensory retina, predominantly occurring within the nerve fibre layer.(Option A ruled out)
  • The fovea often displays a cystoid structure with radiating striation of the superficial retinal layers.
  • In 50% of cases, a peripheral retinoschisis is found in the inferior temporal quadrant, but it typically does not extend up to the ora, differentiating it from a retinal detachment.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sex-linked juvenile retinoschisis involves a characteristic splitting of the sensory retina in the nerve fibre layer.
  • The condition is typically bilateral and presents with specific electrophysiological findings: a subnormal ERG and a normal EOG.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl with deafness is referred by ENT dept to Ophthalmology for assessment of dimness of vision. On ocular examination she is found to have myopia, liquefied vitreous and retinal detachment in right eye. Other features include: flat nasal bridge, cleft palate, and stiff, painful, prominent and hyperextensible joints. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a 3-year-old girl with deafness, dimness of vision, myopia, liquefied vitreous, retinal detachment, flat nasal bridge, cleft palate, and stiff, painful, prominent and hyperextensible joints is highly consistent with Stickler syndrome, also known as hereditary arthro-ophthalmopathy. This is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder.

  • Ocular features of Stickler syndrome include:
    • The vitreous is liquefied and shows syneresis, appearing as an optically empty vitreous cavity.
    • Progressive myopia is very common.
    • Radial lattice-like degeneration with pigmentary changes and vascular sheathing can be observed.
    • Bilateral retinal detachment may occur in 30% of cases, making it the commonest inherited cause of retinal detachment in children.
    • Ectopia lentis is occasionally associated.
    • Pre-senile cataract occurs in 50% of cases.
  • Orofacial abnormalities associated with Stickler syndrome include a flattened nasal bridge, maxillary hypoplasia, cleft palate, and a high arched palate.
  • Arthropathy is characterized by stiff, painful, prominent, and hyperextensible large joints.
  • Other features include deafness and mitral valve prolapse.

Explanation of Other Options:

Favre-Goldmann Syndrome (Option A): Favre-Goldmann syndrome is a rare form of X-linked retinoschisis, characterized by severe night blindness, peripheral retinoschisis, and sometimes vitreous veils. While it involves retinal issues, it does not typically include the widespread systemic features like joint abnormalities, deafness, and facial dysmorphism seen in this patient.

Brown Syndrome (Option C): Brown syndrome is an ocular motility disorder characterized by a restriction of elevation in adduction due to a problem with the superior oblique tendon sheath. It is a localized eye condition and does not involve systemic features like deafness, joint problems, or facial anomalies.

Wolfram Syndrome (Option D): Wolfram syndrome (DIDMOAD syndrome) is characterized by Diabetes Insipidus, Diabetes Mellitus, Optic Atrophy, and Deafness. While it includes deafness and optic atrophy (leading to vision loss), it does not typically present with liquefied vitreous and retinal detachment, specific facial abnormalities like flat nasal bridge and cleft palate, or the prominent joint hyperextensibility described.

Key Takeaways:

  • The combination of ocular features (myopia, liquefied vitreous, retinal detachment), deafness, orofacial abnormalities (flat nasal bridge, cleft palate), and joint hyperextensibility is highly characteristic of Stickler syndrome.
  • Stickler syndrome is a significant cause of inherited retinal detachment in children.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for the following fundus appearance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image of a fundus photo showing an "egg-yolk appearance at the fovea" is highly characteristic of Vitelliform dystrophy of the fovea. This condition is also known as Best disease.

  • Vitelliform dystrophy of the fovea is characterized by a sharply delimited, usually bilateral orange-yellow disc in the foveal region, which resembles the yolk of a fried egg.

Explanation of Other Options:

Stargardt disease (Option A): Stargardt disease is a macular dystrophy that typically presents with central vision loss and often shows a "beaten bronze" macula or pisciform (fish-tail shaped) flecks in the macula, but not the distinct "egg-yolk" lesion.

Fundus flavimaculatus (Option C): Fundus flavimaculatus is an allelic variant of Stargardt disease, characterized by yellow-white flecks scattered throughout the posterior pole and mid-periphery, which may or may not involve the macula. It does not typically present with a solitary "egg-yolk" lesion at the fovea.

Retinitis pigmentosa (Option D): Retinitis pigmentosa is a generalized photoreceptor dystrophy primarily affecting the peripheral retina and causing night blindness and peripheral vision loss. Its fundus appearance includes characteristic bone-spicule pigmentation and attenuated retinal vessels, not an "egg-yolk" lesion at the fovea.

Key Takeaways:

  • A "golden ring sign" is a visual indicator of complete hydrodilineation, confirming the successful separation of the endonucleus from the epinucleus.
  • The "egg-yolk appearance at the fovea" is the classic descriptive sign for Vitelliform dystrophy of the fovea, also known as Best disease.

questions.text: Identify the syndrome associated with vitreoretinal degeneration: Autosomal recessive condition presenting with night blindness in childhood. Vitreous syneresis, retinoschisis and pigmentary changes in retina are characteristic features. ERG is subnormal.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Favre-Goldmann Syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that typically presents in childhood with nyctalopia (night blindness). Key characteristic features include vitreous syneresis (though the cavity is not optically empty), retinoschisis (both central affecting the macula and peripheral), and marked pigmentary changes in the retina similar to retinitis pigmentosa. Additionally, the ERG (electroretinogram) is subnormal.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sturge Weber Syndrome (Option A): Sturge-Weber syndrome is characterized by a facial port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angioma, and glaucoma, but it is not primarily a vitreoretinal degeneration presenting with night blindness, vitreous syneresis, retinoschisis, or pigmentary changes as its defining ocular features.

Stickler Syndrome (Option B): Stickler syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder characterized by progressive myopia, liquefied vitreous (optically empty cavity), retinal detachment (commonest inherited cause in children), and systemic features like deafness, flat nasal bridge, cleft palate, and joint hyper-extensibility. While it involves vitreous liquefaction and retinal issues, its inheritance pattern (autosomal dominant) and specific clinical features (e.g., optically empty vitreous, systemic findings) differentiate it from the description given.

Wagner's Syndrome (Option D): Wagner's syndrome has an autosomal dominant inheritance. While it features vitreous liquefaction with condensed membranes and retinal changes like narrow, sheathed vessels and peripheral pigmented spots, it is autosomal dominant, not autosomal recessive.

Key Takeaways:

  • Favre-Goldmann syndrome is distinguished by its autosomal recessive inheritance, childhood-onset night blindness, and the combination of vitreous syneresis, retinoschisis (central and peripheral), pigmentary changes, and a subnormal ERG.

questions.text: In which of the following disorders is the EOG abnormal and ERG normal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Best disease (also known as Best vitelliform macular dystrophy, BVMD) is the disorder characterized by an abnormal EOG (electrooculogram) and a normal ERG (electroretinogram). This distinct electrophysiological pattern is crucial for its diagnosis.

  • Best disease is a rare autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation of the BEST1 (or VMD2) gene. It typically presents in childhood.
  • It is characterized by bilateral fundus changes resembling an "egg-yolk" at the macula.
  • The primary affected layer is the Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE), with deposition of yellow material within the RPE, subretinal space, and photoreceptor zone.
  • BVMD progresses through 6 clinical stages, with abnormal EOG being present even in the pre-vitelliform stage (Stage I) where vision is normal or has only subtle RPE changes.
  • The EOG is typically affected, showing a reduced Arden ratio (the ratio of Light peak to Dark trough) in both carriers and patients. An Arden ratio of < 1.65 is significantly subnormal.
  • The ERG is typically normal.
  • Dark adaptometry is also normal in Best disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fundus flavimaculatus (Option A): Fundus flavimaculatus is an allelic variant of Stargardt disease. In Stargardt disease, both the ERG and EOG can be normal in early stages, but the ERG may become abnormal as the disease progresses, particularly the cone and rod responses. It does not typically present with a uniquely abnormal EOG and normal ERG in the way Best disease does.

Retinitis pigmentosa (Option B): In Retinitis Pigmentosa, the ERG is typically markedly abnormal or extinguished, reflecting widespread photoreceptor degeneration, especially rods. The EOG is also often abnormal. Therefore, it does not fit the criteria of a normal ERG.

Oguchi disease (Option D): Oguchi disease is a form of congenital stationary night blindness. It is characterized by night blindness and a distinctive golden-yellow or grayish-white discoloration of the fundus (Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon), which disappears after prolonged dark adaptation. While it is a form of stationary night blindness, the ERG is typically abnormal or a specific pattern of ERG changes (e.g., absent scotopic b-wave) is seen, differentiating it from a normal ERG.

Key Takeaways:

  • Best disease (Vitelliform macular dystrophy) is classically identified by an abnormal EOG (reduced Arden ratio) due to RPE dysfunction, while the ERG remains normal as photoreceptor function is initially preserved.
  • This electrophysiological dissociation is a hallmark differentiating it from other retinal dystrophies.

questions.text: Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon is seen in which disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon is a characteristic sign seen in Oguchi disease. This phenomenon refers to the disappearance of the unusual golden-yellow or silver-gray metallic sheen of the fundus after a prolonged period of dark adaptation (three hours or more), leading to the appearance of a normal reddish fundus.

  • Oguchi disease is an autosomal recessive form of congenital stationary night blindness.
  • It is caused by a disruption in the steps of inactivation of rod phototransduction.
  • Patients complain of static nyctalopia (night blindness) since childhood and a preservation of vision in bright light.
  • On examination, patients have normal visual fields, but their fundi have a diffuse or patchy, silver-gray, or golden-yellow metallic sheen, and the retinal vessels stand out in relief against this background.
  • Two genes, Rhodopsin kinase (GRK1) and Arrestin (SAG), are involved in deactivating rhodopsin to stop the phototransduction cascade.

Explanation of Other Options:

Retinal detachment (Option A): Retinal detachment involves the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium and is characterized by symptoms like flashes, floaters, and visual field defects. It does not present with the Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon.

Retinitis pigmentosa (Option B): Retinitis pigmentosa is a progressive retinal dystrophy characterized by night blindness, peripheral vision loss, and bone-spicule pigmentation in the fundus. It involves a subnormal or extinguished ERG, but not the Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon.

Stargardt's disease (Option C): Stargardt's disease is a macular dystrophy causing central vision loss and characteristic macular changes like "beaten bronze" appearance or pisciform flecks. It does not involve night blindness that improves with dark adaptation or the Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon, characterized by a temporary change in fundus coloration after prolonged dark adaptation, is pathognomonic for Oguchi disease.
  • Oguchi disease is a form of congenital stationary night blindness resulting from a defect in rod phototransduction.

questions.text: This classical fundus picture is seen in case of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The provided fundus picture is described as a "dark choroid," a characteristic finding in Stargardt's disease. The "dark" or "silent choroid" sign results from the blockage of early choroidal fluorescence by lipofuscin deposition within the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

  • Stargardt's disease is the most common juvenile macular dystrophy and a frequent heritable cause of central visual dysfunction in young patients.
  • It is most commonly caused by mutations in the ABCA4 gene and is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion.
  • The ABCA4 gene encodes an ATP-binding cassette transmembrane protein expressed by rod outer segments, involved in the transport of all-trans-retinal. Mutations in ABCA4 in Stargardt's disease lead to the accumulation of all-trans-retinal in the photoreceptors and the RPE.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bull's eye maculopathy (Option A): Bull's eye maculopathy is characterized by a central zone of macular atrophy surrounded by a ring of hyperpigmentation, often seen in conditions like chloroquine/hydroxychloroquine toxicity or some cone dystrophies.

Retinitis pigmentosa (Option C): Retinitis pigmentosa is a generalized retinal dystrophy affecting photoreceptors, characterized by progressive night blindness, peripheral vision loss, and bone-spicule pigmentation in the mid-periphery.

Diabetic retinopathy (Option D): Diabetic retinopathy is a microvascular complication of diabetes, characterized by microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, and neovascularization.

Key Takeaways:

  • The presence of a "dark" or "silent choroid" on fundus angiography is a classical and diagnostic sign of Stargardt's disease.
  • This phenomenon is due to the accumulation of lipofuscin within the RPE, which blocks choroidal fluorescence.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with gradual painless decrease of vision for many years. He has been a smoker, hypertensive and diabetic for many years. His retina shows this picture. What is the treatment you would advise?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation of gradual painless vision loss, advanced age (75 years), history of smoking, hypertension, and diabetes (all risk factors for AMD), combined with the fundus picture which appears to show a large area of chorioretinal atrophy, strongly suggests late-stage dry Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD) with geographical atrophy. For this stage of dry AMD, there is currently no effective treatment, and it is associated with a poor prognosis for vision improvement.

  • Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is the most common cause of blindness in the Western world.
  • Risk factors include age over 50 years, hypertension, smoking, high fat intake, and blue light exposure.
  • AMD is characterized by the development of basal laminar deposits and drusen between the RPE and Bruch's membrane.
  • AMD has dry (90%) and wet
  • Dry AMD is further divided into early, intermediate, and late stages.
    • Geographical atrophy is the last stage of dry AMD. It is defined as a large, delineated area of severe chorioretinal atrophy, leading to progressive and irreversible loss of retinal cells and a marked decrease in vision.
    • For Geographical atrophy, no treatment can be done.
  • Wet AMD (Neovascular ARMD):
    • CNVM (Choroidal Neovascularization) are new vessels from the choriocapillaris through a break in the outer aspect of Bruch's membrane into the sub-RPE space.
    • These new vessels are accompanied by fibroblasts and disrupt the normal architecture of the choriocapillaris, Bruch's membrane, and RPE.
    • Within the sub-RPE space, the CNV can leak fluid and blood, and may be accompanied by a serous or hemorrhagic detachment of the RPE.
    • Symptoms of Wet AMD include decreased visual acuity, scotoma, metamorphopsia, and micropsia.
    • A Disciform scar (damage to photoreceptors and remaining outer retina) can form.

Explanation of Other Options:

Intravitreal steroids (Option A): Intravitreal steroids are sometimes used in specific cases of wet AMD, but they are not the primary treatment for dry AMD, especially not for geographical atrophy.

Lasers (Option B): Laser photocoagulation may be considered for extrafoveal CNVM (choroidal neovascularization) in wet AMD, but it is typically not advised for dry AMD or central lesions due to the risk of vision loss. It is not a treatment for geographical atrophy.

Vitamin supplements (Option D): Vitamin supplements (specifically AREDS II formula) are advised for intermediate AMD to slow progression, but they do not reverse geographical atrophy, which is the final stage of dry AMD. For late-stage geographical atrophy, vitamin supplements will not restore lost vision.

Key Takeaways:

  • The fundus picture depicting a large atrophic area in a patient with risk factors for AMD suggests late-stage dry AMD with geographical atrophy.
  • For geographical atrophy, there is no current treatment to restore vision, indicating a poor prognosis.

questions.text: What is correct about this chart
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chart shown in the picture is an Amsler's grid. This grid is primarily useful for patients with Age-Related Macular Degeneration (ARMD), as it is given for their home monitoring.

  • The Amsler's grid has 400 squares and checks 20 degrees of the visual field.
  • Distorted/wavy lines seen on the grid are indicative of macular pathology.
  • Absent lines on the grid are suggestive of optic nerve pathology.

Explanation of Other Options:

It checks 10 of the visual field (Option A): This statement is incorrect. The Amsler's grid checks 20 degrees of the visual field, not 10 degrees.

Distorted lines are seen in optic atrophy (Option C): This statement is incorrect. Distorted or wavy lines on the Amsler's grid are indicative of macular pathology, while absent lines suggest optic nerve pathology.

Absent lines means macular pathology (Option D): This statement is incorrect. Absent lines on the Amsler's grid mean optic nerve pathology, not macular pathology.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Amsler's grid is a simple tool primarily used for home monitoring in ARMD patients.
  • Distorted/wavy lines indicate macular pathology, while absent lines indicate optic nerve pathology.
  • The grid assesses the central 20 degrees of the visual field.

questions.text: A small boy was observed to have nystagmus and cataract. He was also not following light and had developmental delay also. His picture is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation of a small boy with nystagmus, cataract, inability to follow light (indicating severe vision loss), and developmental delay is highly consistent with Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA). LCA is the most severe retinal dystrophy, often leading to blindness by 10 years of age.

  • Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA) is a severe retinal dystrophy where the retina is unable to undergo phototransduction.
  • Children with LCA often exhibit nystagmus.
  • Other ocular signs include sluggish pupillary responses and decreased vision.
  • LCA can be associated with systemic features such as cataract, keratoconus, epilepsy, and mental retardation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tay-Sachs disease (Option A): Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and a cherry-red spot in the macula.

Sandhoff's disease (Option B): Sandhoff's disease is another lysosomal storage disorder, very similar to Tay-Sachs, with progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and often a cherry-red spot. It shares similar distinctions from LCA as Tay-Sachs disease.

Stargardt's disease (Option C): Stargardt's disease is the most common juvenile macular dystrophy, primarily causing central vision loss (often with a "dark choroid" on angiography and macular flecks).

Key Takeaways:

  • Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA) is characterized by severe early-onset vision loss (often leading to blindness by age 10), nystagmus, and can be associated with cataract and mental retardation.
  • It results from the retina's inability to undergo phototransduction.

questions.text: Identify the lesion
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image is consistent with Drusen bodies. Drusen are extracellular deposits composed of lipids, proteins, and cellular debris. They are typically found between the basal lamina of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and the inner layer of the Bruch membrane (BM), appearing as small, yellow deposits during dilated eye exams.

  • Drusen can be classified histopathologically:
    • Basal linear drusen occurs when deposits are found between the basement membrane of the RPE and Bruch's membrane.
    • Basal laminar drusen occurs when deposits are located between the plasma membrane of the RPE and the basement membrane of the RPE.
  • While drusen are seen with normal aging, their size, number, location, and type can indicate an increased risk of developing Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD).

Explanation of Other Options:

Cystoid edema (Option B): Cystoid macular edema involves fluid accumulation in the macula, forming cyst-like spaces, which would appear differently from solid drusen deposits.

Photoreceptor accumulation (Option C): Photoreceptor accumulation is not a typical description for extracellular deposits like drusen; rather, drusen are located external to the photoreceptors.

Disruption of inner BRB (Option D): Disruption of the inner blood-retinal barrier (BRB) is associated with leakage and edema, not the formation of solid extracellular deposits like drusen.

Key Takeaways:

  • Drusen are extracellular deposits located between the RPE and Bruch's membrane, appearing as yellow spots.
  • They are associated with aging and can indicate an increased risk for AMD.
  • Histopathologically, they can be categorized as basal linear or basal laminar based on their specific location relative to the RPE's membranes.

questions.text: 'A' wave of ERG represent
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The a-wave in an Electroretinogram (ERG) is a negative wave, sometimes referred to as the "late receptor potential". It directly reflects the general physiological health of the photoreceptors in the outer retina. The ERG itself is a mass electrical response of the retina to a light stimulus, arising from currents generated by retinal neurons and glial cells.

  • The b-wave, a positive wave, reflects the health of the inner layers of the retina, including the ON bipolar cells and the Muller cells.
  • The c-wave is a slow positive component that follows the b-wave and is generated from the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Implicit time refers to the time occurring between the initiation of the light stimulation (flash) and the peak of a-and b-waves. The a-wave amplitude was measured from baseline to a-wave trough; the b-wave amplitude was measured from a-wave trough to b-wave peak.
  • The ERG provides diagnostic information for various inherited and acquired retinal disorders and can be used to monitor disease progression or evaluate retinal toxicity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Activity of bipolar cells (Option A): The activity of bipolar cells is primarily reflected in the b-wave of the ERG, not the a-wave.

Muller cell activity (Option B): Muller cell activity also contributes to the b-wave of the ERG, not the a-wave.

RPE potential (Option D): The RPE (retinal pigment epithelium) potential is primarily represented by the c-wave of the ERG, not the a-wave.

Key Takeaways:

  • The a-wave of the ERG is a direct measure of photoreceptor activity in the outer retina.
  • Different waves of the ERG (a-wave, b-wave, c-wave) reflect the electrical activity of different retinal layers and cell types.

questions.text: Arden ratio normal value is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The normal value for the Arden ratio is 1.85 or greater. Specifically, an Arden ratio of 1.80 or greater is considered normal. The Arden ratio is calculated by comparing the size of the light peak (Lp) to the dark trough (Dt) in an electrooculogram (EOG). A light peak:dark trough ratio of less than 1.5 is considered abnormal.

  • The Electrooculogram (EOG) measures the cornea-positive standing potential of the eye using skin electrodes.
  • This potential decreases in the dark, reaching its lowest point (dark trough) after 8-12 minutes.
  • When lights are turned on, the potential rises, peaking after about 10 minutes (light peak).
  • The origin of EOG potentials is the pigment epithelium of the retina interacting with the midretina. A normal light rise of the potential requires both a normal pigment epithelium and normal midretinal function.
  • An Arden ratio between 1.65 and 1.80 is considered subnormal, while less than 1.65 is significantly subnormal.
  • The EOG is most commonly used to confirm Best disease, where the EOG will be abnormal while the ERG (electroretinogram) remains normal. The EOG is also used for tracking eye movement.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Arden ratio is a key measurement from the EOG, used to assess the function of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and midretina.
  • A normal Arden ratio is 85 or greater.
  • An abnormal Arden ratio, particularly less than 1.5, is a hallmark of certain retinal conditions like Best disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female came with a decrease in vision after a few months. She has been reported to have hypertension, DM and rheumatoid arthritis for many years. There is a lesion seen in her retina for which FFA was done and is shown below. The pictures are given here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Given the patient's history of rheumatoid arthritis (which often involves long-term use of medications like hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine), along with the complaint of decreased vision, the most likely diagnosis for a retinal lesion with a characteristic appearance is Bull's eye maculopathy. This is a classic presentation of chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine toxic retinopathy. The classic bull's eye maculopathy appearance is where the fovea is surrounded by a ring of depigmentation, followed by a ring of hyperpigmentation.

  • Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can cause toxic retinopathy due to their binding to melanin in the retinal pigmented epithelium (RPE) and direct toxicity to retinal ganglion cells.
  • Early findings may include mottling of the RPE and a blunted foveal reflex. While early toxicity can be asymptomatic, patients with more advanced stages may complain of color vision changes or paracentral scotomas.
  • Since retinal toxicity is usually irreversible, early detection and cessation of the offending agent are crucial.
  • Risk Factors for hydroxychloroquine retinopathy are most influenced by daily dose and duration of use, with lower risk for doses less than 5.0 mg/kg real weight/day for hydroxychloroquine and less than 2.3 mg/kg real weight/day for chloroquine. Patients are at low risk during the first 5 years of treatment.
  • Other associated toxicities can include corneal toxicity (intraepithelial drug deposition, rarely affecting vision) and rare ciliary body dysfunction affecting accommodation.

Other conditions causing bull's eye pattern in macula:

  • Cone Dystrophy
  • Stargardt's disease
  • Chloroquine Retinopathy
  • Clofazimine Toxicity
  • Age-Related Macular Degeneration (some forms)
  • Leber's Congenital Amaurosis
  • Chronic macular hole
  • Inverse Retinitis pigmentosa

Explanation of Other Options:

CME (Cystoid Macular Edema) (Option A): CME involves fluid accumulation in the macula, forming cyst-like spaces. While it causes decreased vision and can be associated with DM, it does not typically present with a "bull's eye" pattern.

CSR (Central Serous Retinopathy) (Option B): CSR involves serous detachment of the neurosensory retina or RPE, often presenting with acute vision loss, metamorphopsia, and micropsia. It does not create a bull's eye appearance.

ARMD (Age-Related Macular Degeneration) (Option D): ARMD is a common cause of vision loss in older adults, characterized by drusen (in dry AMD) or choroidal neovascularization (in wet AMD). While ARMD can cause vision decrease, the classic "bull's eye" maculopathy is not its typical presentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • The clinical scenario, particularly the history of rheumatoid arthritis and the description of the lesion, strongly points to hydroxychloroquine-induced bull's eye maculopathy.
  • This condition is characterized by a specific pattern of depigmentation and hyperpigmentation around the fovea.
  • Early detection and cessation of the offending drug are crucial to prevent irreversible vision loss.

questions.text: This condition can be seen in all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows Angioid streaks. Angioid streaks are bilateral, narrow, irregular lines deep to the retina, radiating from the optic disc, which result from breaks in a weakened Bruch's membrane. Angioid streaks can be associated with conditions listed in options A, B, and C, but are not typically seen in Old retinal detachment.

  • Angioid streaks are associated with numerous systemic diseases, with the most common being Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE). (Option A ruled out)
  • A popular mnemonic used to recall common associations is PEPSI: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum, Ehler-Danlos syndrome, Paget's disease of bone, Sickle cell disease and other hemoglobinopathies, and I
  • Other causes mentioned include Marfan syndrome, abetalipoproteinemia, acromegaly, and diabetes mellitus (DM).(Option C ruled out)
  • High myopia is also a known clinical association with angioid streaks. (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Angioid streaks are breaks in Bruch's membrane, often associated with systemic diseases that affect elastic tissue.
  • Common associations include Pseudoxanthoma elasticum, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Paget's disease, Sickle cell disease, and Diabetes Mellitus. High myopia is also a known association.
  • Old retinal detachment is not a recognized condition in which angioid streaks are typically seen.

questions.text: The most frequent cataract type seen in adult retinitis pigmentosa patient is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most frequent cataract type seen in adult retinitis pigmentosa (RP) patients is Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC). These are recognized as the most common anterior segment complication of RP.

  • The opacity of the lens generally occurs at the mid-stage of the disease course, with obvious clinical symptoms and signs.
  • The major symptom associated with these complicated cataracts (specifically PSCs) is glare, especially in bright light.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior polar (Option B): Anterior polar cataracts are typically congenital or develop early in life and are located on the anterior surface of the lens capsule. They are not specifically highlighted as the most frequent type in adult RP patients.

Cortical (Option C): Cortical cataracts involve the lens cortex and can present with various opacities (e.g., spoke-like, wedge-shaped). While cortical cataracts can occur, PSC as the most common type in RP.

Mixed (Option D): Mixed cataracts imply a combination of types. While RP patients may develop other cataract types, PSC as the most frequent and characteristic.

Key Takeaways:

  • Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC) is the most common cataract type in adult retinitis pigmentosa patients.
  • PSCs in RP often present with glare as a prominent symptom.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in RP except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement that prominent retinal vessels are seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is incorrect. In RP, the vessels become thin and attenuated, which is a highly consistent sign of the disease.

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is characterized by:

  • Attenuated (thin) retinal vessels.
  • Tunnel vision (progressive constriction of the visual field) is a common symptom due to peripheral retinal degeneration. (Option B ruled out)
  • Pale disc (waxy pallor of the optic disc) can be a feature, reflecting optic nerve atrophy. (Option C ruled out)
  • Bony spicules (bone-spicule pigmentation) are characteristic pigmentary changes in the peripheral retina. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • A key characteristic of Retinitis Pigmentosa is attenuated (thin) retinal vessels, not prominent ones.
  • Other common findings in RP include tunnel vision, optic disc pallor, and characteristic bone-spicule pigmentation.
